answers: Roman roads [accept via or viae or ways]
parts: These locations served as the center of daily life in Roman cities as well as the meeting place for the Senate. The last imperial one of these built was designed by Apollodorus of Damascus and named after the emperor Trajan.
More than 400,000 km of these structures helped link the Roman Empire together. Spartacus and his followers were crucified along one of these structures.
These buildings can be distinguished between their urbana and rustica types, and were usually only owned by wealthy citizens. Hadrian had one built for himself in Tivoli.

answers: Svetambara or Digambara [prompt on sky-clad and white-clad]
parts: Name this Indian religion that holds sacred the principle of ahimsa or extreme nonviolence.
Jains are divided into two sects which have different beliefs about a number of issues that include the veneration of icons and the reincarnation of women; name either.
This most recent ford-maker is said to have been born after Queen Trishala dreamed about a four-tusked elephant entering her womb.

answers: choli [accept ravike (South India) and cholo (Nepal)] <Other Fine Arts, AH><ed. OC>
parts: Name this traditional Japanese garment that is wrapped around the body and secured from the back by a sash called an obi. It is commonly worn by Japanese women today, most popularly on special occasions.
The internet exploded in May 2018 when an American girl wore this type of traditional Manchu Chinese dress to a high school prom. It was heavily popularized by upper-class women in 1920s Shanghai.
Women from the Indian subcontinent often wear the Sari draped over this garment, a midriff-baring blouse.

answers: cyanobacteria [or blue-green algae or Cyanophyta, prompt on bacteria, do not accept or prompt on “algae” or “green algae”]]
cell membrane [accept anything with membrane] <Biology, KLei><ed. VS>
parts: Name this phylum of photosynthetic prokaryotes that produce oxygen and are sometimes named for their color.
Part of this theory proposed by Lynn Margulis states that chloroplasts originated from cyanobacteria that were engulfed by other cells.

One piece of evidence for endosymbiosis is the presence of cardiolipin only on the inner one of these structures in mitochondria. One of these structures described as a phospholipid bilayer is sometimes surrounded by a cell wall.

answers: Johann Sebastian Bach [prompt on Bach, do not accept or prompt on “Carl Philip Emmanuel Bach”]
parts: This deeply religious composer produced most of his works for church services. He composed St. Matthew’s Passion and the Brandenburg Concertos.
Bach was a master of this compositional technique, the presence of multiple voices that are harmonically interdependent but are similar in rhythm and contour.

A common example of contrapuntal music is this form, in which a theme is introduced by a single voice and is imitated throughout the rest of the piece. Bach paired these works with préludes in The Well-Tempered Clavier.
Name this play in which Sam and Hally’s friendship is symbolized by a shabby kite.
Master Harold...and the Boys was written by Athol Fugard, a compatriot of this author. She wrote such novels as Burger’s Daughter and July’s People.
Fugard and Gordimer both hailed from this country and addressed its policy of apartheid in their works.
Name this subfield of philosophy that concerns itself with moral questions of right and wrong.
This approach to ethics that was popularized by a namesake work by John Stuart Mill argues that the best action is ensures the greatest well-being for the greatest number of people.
Utilitarianism is a subset of a diverse class of this theory, which holds that the rightness of an action ultimately stems from the action’s results.

George Orwell’s Animal Farm sees this pig become leader of Manor Farm after the Battle of the Cowshed. He eliminates his rival Snowball and takes credit for plans to build a windmill in an allegory for the Great Turning.
This children’s novel by E.B. White chronicles the friendship between a pig named Wilbur and a barn spider.
One of the main characters in this modern-day retelling of the Iliad is Major Plunkett, a pig farmer who researches the history of St. Lucia.

answers: Judith beheading Holofernes [accept equivalents like Judith slaying Holofernes]
parts: Name this controversial African-American artist known for his naturalistic depictions of African-Americans in place of traditional subjects in scenes from the Western Art-Historical canon.

One source of controversy resulted from Wiley’s racially-charged rendition of this classical scene rendered most famously by Caravaggio and Artemisia Gentileschi. It derives from the Hebrew text the Book of Judith.
Wiley’s reputation was cemented by monumental pieces like his 2005 work Napoleon Leading the Army Over the Alps, a reinterpretation of a similarly-named work by this Neoclassical French artist.

answers: honeybees [accept Apis, prompt on bees, do not accept “bumblebee”]
fixed action pattern [or FAP, accept modal action pattern]
parts: Tinbergen performed research on these animals, determining that they liked yellow and blue models of flowers but would only land on them if scent was applied. Eggs of these animals are laid in honeycombs.

Tinbergen also found that male sticklebacks invariably attacked models with red bellies, even if they were unrealistic, an example of this type of behavior sequence. It is a response to a sign stimulus or releaser.
Tinbergen defined this many questions to explain animal behavior. This is twice the number of Lotka–Volterra equations.
Name this novel that focuses on a doctor’s wife and her affairs with Leon and Rodolphe. At the end of the novel, that woman commits suicide by eating arsenic.
Madame Bovary was written by this French author of A Sentimental Education.
In Madame Bovary, Emma is devastated when her dog of this name runs away. In Hugo’s The Hunchback of Notre Dame, Esmeralda’s pet goat has this name.
Name this act which regulated sanitary standards and prohibited the mislabeling of certain consumables. It was passed alongside the Meat Inspection Act.

The Poison Squad argues that Dr. Wiley’s efforts became synonymous in the public mind with the works of this muckraker. This socialist penned a novel that garnered widespread public support for the Meat Inspection Act.
Dr. Wiley led a truth in labeling case against this company, arguing that its name shouldn’t be used because its products no longer contained cocaine.

answers: Newton’s second law [do not accept “Newton's law”]
linear momentum [do not accept “angular momentum”] <Physics, CT><ed. AB>
parts: Name these vehicles. An equation named after Tsiolkovsky [["sigh-ul-kov-sky”]] gives the maximum difference in velocity for these vehicles as the exhaust velocity times the log of the ratio of the initial and final mass.
The Tsiolkovsky rocket equation can be derived from this law which states that force equals mass times acceleration.
Newton’s second law implies that force is the derivative of this quantity with respect to time. Change in this quantity is known as impulse.

answers: Boko Haram [accept Islamic State in West Africa] <Current Events, AK and KLu><ed. AK and Klu>
parts: Name this current president of an African country. In 2015, this leader of the APC defeated incumbent president Goodluck Jonathan.
Buhari is president of this country. As leader of this country, Buhari oversees its oil industry centered in cities such as Lagos and Port Harcourt.
In 2016, Buhari’s government negotiated a deal with this terrorist group for the release of 21 Chibok girls. This terrorist group is based in the Borno state of northeast Nigeria.

answers: Voicenotes <Pop Culture/Mixed Academic, CZ><ed. KLu and AK>
parts: This single’s music video was the most-watched YouTube video of all time before being dethroned by “Despacito.” Its lyrics include, “It’s been a long day without you, my friend.”
Collaborating with Wiz Khalifa, “See You Again” was this singer’s debut single. His other hits include “We Don’t Talk Anymore” with Selena Gomez and “Attention.”
Puth created this second studio album of his entirely by himself. Its singles include “How Long” and “Done for Me,” featuring Kehlani.

answers: Jomo Kenyatta [prompt on Kenyatta; do not accept or prompt on “Uhuru Kenyatta”]
Jean-Bedel Bokassa [accept Bokassa I or Salah Eddine Ahmed Bokassa] <World History, AK><ed. AH>
parts: Gamal Abdel Nasser led a coup in this country against Muhammad Naguib, promoting the principles of Pan-Arabism and anti-imperialism by nationalizing the Suez Canal.
This first president of Kenya was charged with masterminding the Mau Mau Uprising against the British Empire and was given the honorary title of “Mzee” by his people.
This dictator of the Central African Republic was noted for his alleged cannibalism. However, he is perhaps most famous for spending ⅓ of his country’s GDP on an absurd imperial coronation ceremony.

answers: magical realism [accept marvelous realism, do not accept or prompt on realism] <Non-epic Poetry, AK><ed. OC>
parts: Identify this author of “Nuestra America” and the collection Versos Sencillos, which contains the patriotic song “Guantanamera.”
In his essay “Nuestra America,” Martí expressed his devotion to the independence of this country, his homeland. Martí was born in Havana, the capital city of this country.

Another Cuban author was Alejo Carpentier, who pioneered this literary genre through his novel The Kingdom of this World. This genre is characterized by fantastical elements combined with a realistic perspective of the world.

answers: electron capture [accept K-electron capture, L-electron capture, prompt on inverse beta decay, but do not accept or prompt on just “beta decay”] <Chemistry, CT><ed. KLei>
parts: Name this device, which produces clicking noises corresponding to the amount of ionizing radiation.
This inert gas is often used to fill the GM tube in Geiger counters. It has atomic number 18 and symbol Ar.
Potassium-argon dating uses the decay of potassium-40 to argon-40, which occurs via this process. This process increases the number of neutrons in the nucleus by one and emits an electron neutrino.
Name this political and economic entity made up of 28 member states that are primarily located in Europe. Recently, United Kingdom’s “Brexit” movement targeted an exit from this organization.
The European Union was created through a treaty signed in this Dutch city, located on the Meuse River.

This is the name given to this geographical union of 26 EU member nations who have agreed to adhere to open border policies. Border control has recently be strengthened in the wake of the European Migrant Crisis.
Zeus turned this daughter of Inachus into a white heifer in order to protect her from the wrath of Hera. Hera was not fooled, however, and sent a gadfly to chase her around the world.
In another story, Zeus appeared before Leda as this white avian animal, which led to the conception of Helen and the Dioscuri.
When Hera tricked Semele into asking Zeus to appear in his true lightning-accompanied form, Zeus was forced to stitch the infant Dionysus into this body part of his to save him from the ensuing fire.
